Great vid series - but I'd argue if two points (A-B) do not move relative to each other only the physical distance between them is absolute but the field distance (space) between them is NOT. Because when A-B moves relative to the backdrop of space the field distance between the fixed A-B system actually increases - hence the reason c's elapsed time between them increases. Your Lorentz mechanism showed this - when the distance between A-B points on your mechanism increased the elapsed time of c between said points increased causing  time dilation. The reason this happens is because the emission of a photon is an event (which does not move) and if said emission takes place at point A in a moving A-B system then said A-B system is moving relative to the emission point (non moving event) of the photon. Thus, the field distance between A-B increases because as the system is moving, c is propagating across A-B trying to reach point B which is moving away from the emission point effectively increasing the field distance between A-B. If you look at your mechanism you'll see that the elapsed time of c between points is directly proportional to the field distance between the points. If you were to measure spin of a particle, it is physically impossible to know more than one component of particle spin direction at any one time. However, the very act of measuring a second cardinal spin direction changes the first observational cardinal direction of particle spin you had already obtained. Since quantum observables are considered to be in superposition, universally you are only observing one outcome. Using just one cardinal direction in space, you cannot know with certainty what direction the particle is spinning in or moving toward. Henceforward, the Heisenberg uncertainty principle implies it is impossible to know the position and direction (or momentum in consequence) of any particle simultaneously anywhere in the universe since there are three (or more) dimensions of space.

The fact the actual distance between points is invariant (even those he perceived distances is not) seems to indicate that there is in fact some absolute reference, in this case the sheet of paper that you are drawing the diagrams.

Now if the universe is expanding does that mean the paper is expanding as well? And if so (and the distance between two points increases by that amount of expansion) seems to indicate that there may be two sheets of paper, one in which the drawing is own and the other that has a fixed grid from which one can measure that increase in distance.

Hence their seems to be three different kinds of measurements.

1. The sensed measurements as defined by the observer's frame of reference (ala Relativity)

2. The expanding universe sheet of paper that is stretched (with the drawings stretched as well that causes even two non moving world lines to change in distance due to that expansion where the grid lines on that paper are not fixed by stretch with the paper.

3. a fixed under layer of paper that determines absolute distances with a fixed grid.

It seems we can sense 1 directly, infer 2 by Doppler shifts and the like but 3 is not directly observable other than we can infer it in that actual change of distances (be it from motion or expansion) is invariant and hence the tic marks that one measure that change in actual distance seem to be invariant as well.

Or to use your relativity machine there is 1. the pieces that move on your machine,
2. the machine itself that say if it were made of rubber could be stretched and
3. the table the machine sets on that if fixed from which you can measure the distance due to the pieces moving and the machine being stretched.

So this all boils down to the fact that translations and rotations (as well as reflections and glide reflections) are isometric on the euclidean plane. Since all frames of reference which are static relative to each other are just compositions of rotations and translations, distances are preserved under a change of (static) frame of reference. (They also form a group under composition, leading to some nice algebraic properties.)

I have a slight problem with Your presentation: You did not make a clear distinction between pure spatial and spacetime diagramms in one important way.
In spatial diagramms the physics does not change if we translate, scale or rotate, but in spacetime diagramms we CANNOT rotate like spatial diagramms, because the time coordinate is special.

This has to do with the fact that speed of light is constant and not infinite, thus requiring us to use Lorentz transformations and, in particular, boosts or "time-space-rotations". But I guess You will make this crucial distinction in your next videos about Lorentz transformations, I hope. Thanks for Your work, lose these vids (as a physics student).

Honestly, you make a simple concept far more complex than it needs to be by refusing to bring up normal vectors. That's all a coordinate system is - an origin point and several linearly independent vectors. Every other point in the vector space can then be described as a sum of those origin vectors, potentially weighted by scalars. I get that the attempt here is to represent vector mathematics "in layman's terms" by using cats and sticks, but I genuinely find that harder to follow. The rules of vector mathematics - at least depicted visually - aren't really all that complex.

At 3.37 you explain how relativity can influence the x,y coordinates. Why would we represent a 3 dimensional object on a 2 dimensional plane?

When we think of relativity. The scales of relativity give perspective. Instead of looking at the individual. We should be looking at how atoms arrange themselves according to the closest largest mass. E.g. the individual is relative to the earth, the earth is relative to the sun, the sun is relative to the milky way blackhole etc.

For every relative frame (planet, star, galaxy) couldn't we use x,y,z coordinates to navigate where individual particles are.

The last dimension will be SpaceTime, where you still have x,y,z but each of those coordinates are intertwined with time (t) so the x,y,z coordinates began at (0,0) and continue infinitely in their respective direction.

So in the end, we need 3 dimensional coordinates for each frame of relativity, and the base diagram will include time.

The reason time shouldn't be used in the relative perspective is due to the orderly nature, that time is relative to the object it is orbitting. Therefore an x,y,z coordinate can be associated with a relative time. E.g. at March 23rd every year the planet moves into these coordinates.
The distance between the Earth and the Moon isn't a universal truth. At higher speeds the distance shortens.
